{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3376053,"name":"Itay","username":"Gheriani","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gheriani/{size}/225844_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T19:52:17.350Z","cooked":"

Hi, in the past years me and my team used clamping collars to hold things as gears, shafts wheels and more and then we moved on to tapping the ends of shafts and using a bolt with a washer, this off season we want to try using retaining rings and e-clips.

we would love to hear feedback from Someone who used e-clips or retaining rings on shafts in the past? We would like to know everything about it, what the pros and cons of it compared to bolts and what is your experience and personal opinion about it‚Ä¶

How hard is it to manufacture and what is the best way(we have a lathe)? Where can you buy it from? What tools do we need to buy to work with it? how to model it in 3D modeling software?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T19:52:17.350Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1787,"reads":451,"readers_count":450,"score":9035.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Itay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2023"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/1","custom_user_title":"2023","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3376068,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:29:21.917Z","cooked":"

Con, the one you just had in your hand and were about to snap into place is now half way across the shop‚Ä¶

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:29:45.392Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":411,"readers_count":410,"score":252.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":15}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/2","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376070,"name":"Brandon Liatys","username":"Brandon_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brandon_l/{size}/225700_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:30:50.445Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm a fan of just tapping a hole in the end of the shaft and putting a bolt and washer in to use the bearing that‚Äôs usually at the end of the shaft to retain everything. Requires a nice bearing press fit but you can also use a bearing hat

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:31:25.583Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":401,"readers_count":400,"score":120.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Brandon Liatys","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9288,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"üü©üü©üü©üü©üü©üü©"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/3","custom_user_title":"üü©üü©üü©üü©üü©üü©","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376077,"name":"","username":"DunaganM","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c4cdca/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:45:51.801Z","cooked":"

Shaft clips are awesome for teams with lathes. We use them pretty much everywhere one might use a bolt and washer for retainment. E-eclips are also good, and the tradeoffs are basically as follows: with shaft clips you need shaft clip pliers to use them, they are pretty cheap and make it pretty easy to use. With e-clips you only need a flat head screwdriver and the clip can go on without needing to slip them on the end of the shaft, but they tend to fly off into the ether if you stop paying attention to what your doing.

Both ring clips and e clips can be bought on McMaster, or at most fastener sellers. They are sized according to the groove they are designed to fit in but they will clamp a little tighter than that diameter. One recommendation on sizing is to take into account the shaft size it‚Äôs going over, not just the groove diameter, for thunder hex we use 13mm clips on .5 grooves, which is technically to small a groove, but if you get 1/2 in clips they deform too much during installation. The advantage of using a .5 in groove with hex is you don‚Äôt have to measure on the lathe, just go until all the black is gone.

As far as tooling goes you will need grooving tools that match the thickness specified for the clip. The thickness is not too critical though, so as long as the groove is wider than the clip you should be fine. I believe WCP sells the right tooling, but you can also look with your local tooling suppliers, or order from McMaster.

Another tip is don‚Äôt reuse clips, usually they deform when you take them off, and after a few cycles they will be loose, On the bright side, don‚Äôt be gentle taking them off if you‚Äôre not reusing them, most of the headaches trying to take them off come from being gentle instead of just mangling the thing and replacing it.

As for modeling, there are feature scripts to help you, but I generally just do a cut extrude into the shaft to make the feature. We generally put .002 in of clearance from the last retained item to the start of the groove, our grooves are . 050, and then we add 1x the thickness of the groove after that to retain the clip in the groove. So for us, a clip takes up . 102in of shaft real estate.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:53:45.396Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":375,"readers_count":374,"score":225.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376082,"name":"","username":"DunaganM","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c4cdca/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:48:29.879Z","cooked":"

I will add that the reason we use them is they are
a. Lighter than bolts and washer
b. Faster to manufacture since grooving for us is faster than tapping
c. More flexible since the takeup. Less space and can be put in the middle of shafts.
d. (This is the big one) They are a lot more robust in general since they can‚Äôt vibrate loose.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:48:29.879Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":63.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":41375,"username":"DunaganM","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c4cdca/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376084,"name":"Brendan Manning","username":"BrendanManning","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:48:59.366Z","cooked":"

The biggest obstacle I can think of is that they basically require a lathe to cut grooves for them. Retaining rings are nice because you don‚Äôt have to worry about them loosening with use like a bolt. Although that only applies if they are seated properly. My team had some issues with retaining rings on the WCP single speed gearboxes coming off in 2023. This was due to a combination of a relatively small ledge that I suspect had worn down/filled with debris during use and overextending the retaining rings a bit to get them on. So I would say watch for those type of things with retaining rings. We have had a lot of success with e-clips for various uses and they are nice for being able to hold something in place at locations other than the end of the shaft as well as just being a lighter and probably lower profile (not sure on that one) attachment method than a bolt or shaft collar.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:48:59.366Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":311,"readers_count":310,"score":77.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Brendan Manning","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"NEU; 4761, 777 Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/6","custom_user_title":"NEU; 4761, 777 Alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376088,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T20:51:38.495Z","cooked":"
BrendanManning:

The biggest obstacle I can think of is that they basically require a lathe to cut grooves for them

Can I intrest you in a cordless drill and a hacksaw?

XD

I said basically for a reason. Can I have a Dremel with a cutting wheel instead of a hacksaw?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T20:52:48.742Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":280,"readers_count":279,"score":61.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Brendan Manning","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"NEU; 4761, 777 Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/8","custom_user_title":"NEU; 4761, 777 Alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376392,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T11:53:58.630Z","cooked":"

If using an external retaining ring on hex rod, be sure to lathe down the end of the rod beyond the ring groove to round. Stretching a 1/2" round ring (for example) over 1/2" hex rod will likely deform it permanently.

image738√ó498 71.9 KB

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-29T11:53:58.630Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":218,"readers_count":217,"score":88.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/6/56f5722725d59e284147987955fa3de0134b81a4.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376393,"name":"Eli Hamaker","username":"EllectricHam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ellectricham/{size}/225850_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T12:05:32.754Z","cooked":"

The groove in the shaft for the retaining clip or e-clip can be a breaking point. So be careful using them in high load and critical environments

For modeling the groove we have a hidden body inside of the component for our e-clips. We then use combine and delete to remove the material from shaft. This allows us to not have to think about the required groove dimensions every time for a specific e-clip

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-29T12:09:40.774Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":212,"readers_count":211,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"Eli Hamaker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48876,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"323 Student"},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/10","custom_user_title":"323 Student","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376396,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T12:17:58.010Z","cooked":"
EllectricHam:

The groove in the shaft for the retaining clip or e-clip can be a breaking point. So be careful using them in high load and critical environments

While groves are a stress riser, snap rings and eclips really should go on the ends of shafts on the outside of bearings and therefore will not be subject to significant bending or torsion. Axial stresses are generally relatively small so I wouldn‚Äôt really worry about breaking a shaft at one of the groves as long as you are putting them on the ouside.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-04-29T12:17:58.010Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":84.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464806,"topic_slug":"retaining-rings-and-e-clips","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/retaining-rings-and-e-clips/464806/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376405,"name":"George C","username":"George_C","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/george_c/{size}/156470_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T12:41:28.765Z","cooked":"

E clips are not adjustable along a shaft. Consider using an E clip on one end and a shaft collar on the other. Also consider one of these. McMaster-Carr

Rather than buying a specific cutter, it‚Äôs easy to grind a piece of cutter stock to the correct width.

You can also get E-clips that are bent (like a wave spring washer), so they can occupy a wider groove. They‚Äôre good if you don‚Äôt have a narrow enough cutting tool, or need a more forgiving positional tolerance.

Gheriani:

(we have a lathe)

So, general question here: If you‚Äôre not using your lathe right now to cut slots for retaining rings, what do you use it for? That‚Äôs the only application for a lathe than I can think of in FIRST. (But, I‚Äôm not very creative‚Ä¶)

Here is the short list of items we use for e-clips:.

E-Clips, for 1/2" OD, Black-Phosphate 1060-1090 Spring Steel
1.5mm Width Grove Lathe Tool
E-Clilp Insertion Tool

The e-clip (Side Mount External Retaining Rings) listed above on McM-Carr have spec of 0.045+.003‚Äù groove width but the 1.5mm width cutter gives little extra clearance making installation easier. Not listed is the screwdriver we use to remove the e-clip.

Typical usage is on gearbox 1/2‚Äù hex shafts.

IMG_01882360√ó1640 11.9 MB

I disagree. Our conventional lathe gets a lot of use. Loads of standoffs, large shaft collars, cylinder mounts, pulleys, winch drums, hubs, bushings, shafts etc. We also 3D prints some of those parts but when strength is really important‚Ä¶. Plus the lathe frequently faster. I bought the Canadian made lathe below for $1200 on kijiji. There‚Äôs frequently lineup to use it. Plus there‚Äôs the satisfaction kids get in learning how to use it
